awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mass Extinction Ecological Response and Recovery in the Cretaceous/Paleogene Gulf Coastal Plain
awd_abstract_narration:
It is largely unknown how marine animals today will respond to current and future environmental change. This research is using the geologic record of a mass extinction event 66 million years ago as a natural laboratory to understand habitat loss and species survival during rapid environmental changes. The systematically collected paleo-environment and fossil data are the foundation of immersive, online 'Virtual Field Experiences' that engage students with the field collection and lab processing methods of Earth Sciences research. Online experiences and lesson plans aligned with Next Generation Science Standards are broadly available through well-known online portals and disseminated to teachers in the Gulf Coast states.

Periods of extreme, rapid environmental change in Earth history are informative for predicting current and future survivorship in response to changing climate. These events also provide the opportunity to test hypotheses on macroevolutionary pattern and process. This project involves compiling species occurrences and paleoenvironments across the end-Cretaceous mass extinction (~66 Ma) in the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain. Topics of investigation include (1) the impact of available suitable habitat and habitat continuity on extinction potential; (2) the impact of extreme environmental change on patterns of niche stability within species, and phylogenetic niche conservation within clades; and (3) the influence of extreme environmental change on macroecological shifts in body size and physiological flexibility. This research supports three female early-career PIs, and graduate and undergraduate students at five institutions (two of which serve non-traditional, minority-majority student populations) are trained in field, laboratory, and analytical Earth Science. Two Virtual Field Experiences with high school-level lesson plans will emphasize hypothesis testing and the significance of extinction events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported science advancement and public engagement with science in three main ways: (1) cutting edge and multi-disciplinary research to better understand extinction vulnerability across a major extinction in Earth history; (2) disseminating results in meaningful ways to K-12, college, and community members through a virtual field trip showcasing the scientific process from fieldwork to results; and (3) training and mentoring undergraduate and graduate students in paleobiological, sedimentological, and geochemical science, specifically among historically underrepresented groups.

 

This work compiled fossil species occurrences and a dataset of paleoenvironments from sedimentological and geochemical proxies across the end-Cretaceous mass extinction (~ 66 million years ago) in the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain (GCP). This extinction particularly interesting because its rate is similar to environmental changes observed today (years/decades vs. 10,000s years); it is also famous as it was triggered by an asteroid impact that killed all non-avian dinosaurs, and in total ~ 70% of species globally. Topics of investigation included (1) the impact of available habitat on extinction potential; (2) the impact of extreme environmental change on patterns of niche stability within species, and phylogenetic niche conservation within clades (i.e., modification or not in environmental preferences, such as temperature or salinity tolerances in the ocean); and (3) the influence of extreme environmental change on ecological shifts in body size and physiology. This research also supported three female early-career PIs, and trained graduate and undergraduate students at five institutions (two of which serve non-traditional, minor-majority student populations) in field, laboratory, and analytical Earth Science.

 

Our work produced a systematically collected database of paleoenvironmental and fossil data that is publicly available through publications in science journals and in free online repositories at PI institutions; these data are useful and accessible to educators, researchers, and industry professionals. Major results from this research, to date, supported that: extinction survivorship was not tightly corrected to geographic range size and predicted geographic range size increases were observed for all species (survivors and those that went extinct); stable niches were more likely to be observed during pre-mass extinction intervals than across the mass extinction interval – this is intuitive since the rate and magnitude of environmental change was much larger across the mass extinction interval vs. intervals prior; the source and type of paleoenvironmental data used in ecological models give different results, which requires more research to resolve; biostratigraphic work demonstrated an incredible rock outcrop that preserves the first 40,000 years after the extinction event (sampling resolution not previously observed in regional sites); this period shows a switch from sediment dominated by marine organic material to one of terrestrial organic material and back to marine – suggests post-extinction terrestrial habitat degradation resulted in significant run-off of terrestrial sediment to the ocean; and paleo-temperature reconstructions derived from stable isotope analyses suggest that local-to-regional riverine input modified the stable isotope signature of the ocean in shallow, nearshore environments across this interval.

 

The broader impacts of this work engaged ~ 20 students (1/3 undergraduate; 2/3 graduate) and several postdocs in fieldwork; nearly all continued with project-related research after this experience and produced research presentations at regional and annual professional science meetings and manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication in science journals (some published; many in stages of preparation, revision, review). In this sense the project successfully provided positive and engaging mentorship to early-career researchers at several career stages in several aspects of science and professional development: field methods/ethics, data collection and management, laboratory measurements/practices, data interpretation/hypothesis evaluation, and presentation of results to our research community. This is particularly important since most of our mentees were from underrepresented groups (including ethnicity, race, gender identification, sexuality, and socioeconomic status). Participants partnered with Co-PIs with expertise in geochemistry (paleoenvironmental reconstructions), phylogenetics (reconstructions of evolutionary history), and sedimentology/biostratigraphy (paleoenvironmental and relative time reconstructions). These experiences enriched academic programs and provided networking opportunities important for the next stages of career development – e.g., graduate education, postdoctoral research positions, or industry occupations.

 

Our other major broader impact project was the development of a virtual field experience (VFE) that showcased the research process from field to publication, as well as the background and interests of project participants (PIs and students). Fieldwork completed during this project in the GCP produced photo and video media, including interviews with students and PIs about the general geological/biological setting and research goals, footage of specimen sampling and stratigraphic sectioning, and images of the human process of identifying fossils and packing them for shipping to home institutions. Continued footage of the curation, analysis, and results presentation processes have also been collected to incorporate into the VFE. VFEs were imperative to engaging education during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, but they are also incredible and under-utilized resources in general given that educators are not always able to bring students into the field, lab, or museum.
